questions.text: A 52-year-old woman on treatment for breast cancer presented with headaches and vomiting. CSF cytology showed malignant cells. MRI revealed leptomeningeal enhancement suggestive​ of metastases. Which of the following meningeal layers are affected?

choices.text: Dura mater, arachnoid  mater, and piamater

questions.solution:
Leptomeninges refer to the arachnoid mater and pia mater.

Terminologies for meninges:

  • Outer Pachymeninx - Dura mater
  • Inner Leptomeninges  - Arachnoid + Pia mater (L-AP)

Radiological importance: Pachymeningeal and leptomeningeal enhancement may be diffuse or focal and can aid in the diagnosis of some conditions. 

Conditions that may show meningeal enhancement: 

  • Meningitis
  • Encephalitis 
  • Tumors 
  • Metastasis
  • Inflammatory vasculitides
  • Post-ictal 
  • Post-traumatic and post-operative scarring 

The MRI of medulloblastoma below shows leptomeningeal enhancement (arrows).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about meninges is false?

choices.text: Endosteal layer of the dura mater is the periosteum of skull bones
Meningeal layer divides the cranial cavity into freely communicating spaces
Dural venous sinuses are present between the endosteal and the meningeal layer
Both endosteal and meningeal layer contain fibroblasts and osteoblasts

questions.solution:
Both the endosteal and meningeal layers contain fibroblasts, but only the endosteal layer contains osteoblasts.

The dura mater is made of the following 2 layers:

Endosteal layer Meningeal layer
Periosteum of the skull bones Dura mater proper
Contains fibroblasts and osteoblasts Contains only fibroblasts (no osteoblasts)
Not continuous with the spinal dura mater Continuous with the spinal dura mater
  It forms 4 septa that divide the cranial cavity into spaces restricting the displacement of the brain

The dural venous sinuses are present between the meningeal and the endosteal layer of the dura mater.

The four septa that divide the cranial cavity into freely communicating spaces are: 

  • Falx cerebri
  • Tentorium cerebelli
  • Falx cerebelli
  • Diaphragma sellae

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady presented with sudden onset severe headache, aphasia, and diplopia. Imaging shows an empty delta sign of superior sagittal sinus thrombosis. Choose the correct statement about the dural fold containing the affected sinus.

choices.text: It separates the cerebellum from the occipital lobes of the cerebrum.
It separates the two cerebellar hemispheres.

questions.solution:
The superior sagittal sinus is present in the falx cerebri. Falx cerebri is a sickle-shaped dura mater fold that seperates the two cerebral hemispheres. The superior sagittal sinus runs along its upper fixed margin, the inferior sagittal sinus runs along its lower free margin, and the straight sinus runs along its attachment to the tentorium cerebelli.

Option A: Tentorium cerebelli separates the cerebellum from the occipital lobes of the cerebrum.

Options B and D: Falx cerebelli separates the cerebellar hemispheres and contains the occipital sinus. 

The image below shows the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli.

The image below shows the dural folds.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves do not innervate the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the cranial dura mater and this structure is not innervated by facial nerve branches.

The innervation of the cranial dura mater is derived mainly from:

  • The three divisions of the trigeminal nerve
  • C2 and C3 spinal nerves
  • Cervical sympathetic trunk.

questions.text: Which part of the dura mater is supplied by all the three branches of the trigeminal nerve?

choices.text: Dura of the anterior cranial fossa
Dura of the the  middle cranial fossa
Dura of the posterior cranial fossa

questions.solution:
The dura of the anterior cranial fossa is supplied by all three branches of the trigeminal nerve.

The nerves involved are:

  • Ophthalmic division - anterior and posterior ethmoidal nerves
  • Maxillary division - nervus meningeus medius
  • Mandibular division - nervus spinosus

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the dura covering the marked region?

choices.text: C2-C3 via cranial nerves X and XII
Cranial nerves VII and IX only

questions.solution:
The dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa is mainly innervated by C2 and C3 nerves via cranial nerves X and XII. 

These fibers may be distributed by the vagus and hypoglossal nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply the corresponding region of the dura mater?

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery –  Anterior cranial fossa
Accessory meningeal branch of maxillary artery – Middle cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery – Posterior cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery – Anterior cranial fossa

questions.solution:
The meningeal branch of the internal carotid artery (ICA) does not supply the posterior cranial fossa. It supplies the anterior cranial fossa.

The dura mater is supplied by meningeal arteries that pass along the inner periosteum (endosteum) of the skull over the endosteal layer of the dura and supply the following regions.

Region Arteries
Anterior cranial fossa
  • Meningeal branches of anterior and posterior ethmoid arteries
  • Meningeal branches of internal carotid arteries
  • A branch of the middle meningeal artery
Middle cranial fossa
  • Middle meningeal artery and accessory meningeal branches of the maxillary artery
  • A branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Branches of the internal carotid artery
  • A recurrent branch of the lacrimal artery
Posterior cranial fossa
  • Meningeal branches of the occipital artery
  • Posterior meningeal branches of the vertebral artery
  • Dorsal meningeal and tentorial arteries arising from the meningohypophyseal trunk

questions.text: What is Meckel's cave formed by?

choices.text: Evagination of the lower layer of the falx cerebri
Evagination of lower layer of the tentorium cerebelli

questions.solution:
Evagination of the lower layer of the tentorium cerebelli at the petrous apex is called Meckel's cave.

It is a dural recess in the middle cranial fossa that houses the Gasserian ganglion and proximal rootlets of the trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: A patient with chronic otitis media and mastoiditis develops thrombosis of the sinus marked below. Which of the following sinuses does it drain from?
questions.solution:
The sinus marked in the image is the sigmoid sinus. It drains from the transverse sinus. 

It passes through an S-shaped groove in the mastoid process of the temporal bone, courses over the jugular process of the occipital bone, and emerges posterior to the jugular foramen. 

The sigmoid sinus receives tributaries: 

  • Mastoid emissary veins
  • Condylar emissary veins
  • Venous plexus of the hypoglossal canal
  • Inferior cerebellar veins 
  • Unnamed tributaries from the pons and medulla 

It joins the inferior petrosal sinus to form the internal jugular vein.

Sigmoid/lateral sinus thrombosis occurs as a complication of ear or mastoid infection. 

Related Pearl: Dural Venous Sinuses

Dural venous sinus Drains into
Unpaired sinuses
Superior sagittal sinus Confluence of sinuses or continues as right transverse sinus
Inferior sagittal sinus joins the great cerebral vein to form the straight sinus
 Straight sinus forms the left transverse sinus
Occipital sinus Confluence of sinuses
Paired sinuses
Superior petrosal sinus transverse sinus
Inferior petrosal sinus Internal jugular vein
Transverse sinus continue as sigmoid sinus
Sigmoid sinus continuous with the internal jugular vein
Cavernous sinus Superior and inferior petrosal sinuses

questions.text: A 54-year-old male came to the hospital with a ​severe headache. CT scan revealed an aneurysm of the internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus. Which of the following nerves is likely to be affected first?

choices.text: Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve
Maxillary division of  the trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
The abducens nerve is likely to be affected first.

The abducent nerve runs within the cavernous sinus in close proximity to the internal carotid artery. Therefore, an aneurysm of the ICA may impinge on the nerve and may lead to sixth nerve palsy.

The oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve lie in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. They are involved in the pathologies of the sinus much later. 

The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve does not run through the cavernous sinus or its lateral wall. It passes beneath the dura of the middle cranial fossa underneath the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: A diabetic lady with a history of chronic sinusitis presents with seizures and altered mental status. On examination, she is febrile and you note a left-sided lateral rectus palsy. On fundoscopy, papilledema is present bilaterally.  Which of the following is not a tributary of sinus involved here?
questions.solution:
The history and examination findings suggest cavernous sinus thrombosis.

The deep middle cerebral vein is not a tributary of the cavernous sinus. It joins the anterior cerebral and striate veins to form the basal vein. 

The tributaries of cavernous sinus are:

  • From orbit - superior and inferior ophthalmic veins
  • From cranium - sphenoparietal sinus, superficial middle cerebral vein, inferior cerebral vein.

The cavernous sinus drains into: 

  • Transverse sinus via superior petrosal sinus
  • Internal jugular vein via inferior petrosal sinus
  • Pterygoid plexus of veins via emissary veins
  • Superior ophthalmic vein

The contents of the cavernous venous sinus include:

  • Cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery
  • Perivascular sympathetic plexus
  • Abducens nerve (running through the Dorello’s canal)
  • Oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve as part of the lateral wall.
